awd_abstract_narration:
Neural interfaces will revolutionize disease care for patients of neurological conditions. Today, implantable neurostimulation (NS) devices have seen widespread adoption in the treatment of movement disorders, pain, and epilepsy, and have shown promise in treating psychiatric disorders, memory loss, depression, and more. Clinical neurostimulators have few channels and provide simple electrical pulses that are programmed by a doctor in a process that can take months or even years. There is a need for clinically viable, low-power and miniaturized systems that enable simultaneous stimulation and recording on many channels. Providing simultaneous sensing and closed-loop control will allow devices to automatically optimize parameters for a given outcome and only treat when symptoms are present, reducing side effects and reducing power. Closing the loop can provide dynamically delivered therapies that adjust electrical stimulation in response to a patient's real-time neural state. Furthermore, they will, for the first time, allow clinical researchers to understand the brain's response to stimulation and monitor changes (plasticity) over the long term. The future of medical care centers on wearable and implantable devices that will continuously monitor body functions and autonomously give treatment in an intelligent, closed-loop and well-controlled manner without the need for a doctor's intervention. This future requires broad, interdisciplinary engineering that combines electronics, artificial intelligence and biology. The multidisciplinary nature of this project extends to the long-term educational goals of promoting hands-on bioelectronic science and technology to the next generation of engineers. 
 

This project develops miniaturized and highly integrated devices for closed-loop neuromodulation that combine high channel count neural recording with stimulation in a truly closed-loop manner for the first time. If successful, the proposed work will make significant advancements in two areas. First, low-power, low-noise integrated circuit design techniques will be developed to combine simultaneous stimulation and recording. Stimulation can significantly interfere with neural recording, resulting in large, persistent artifacts that mask or distort the neural signal and obscure reliable biomarker detection. Recording and stimulation circuits will be co-designed to eliminate this interaction. Second, online machine learning algorithms will be developed and integrated in hardware for dynamic closed-loop control. The emphasis will be to develop computationally efficient techniques that minimize the power consumption of the circuit. The two techniques will be combined into a single integrated circuit for multi-channel closed-loop neuromodulation that achieves a small footprint and ultra-low power dissipation that is safe for chronic use in humans. The device will be tested in animal models of disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project’s central hypothesis is that neurotherapeutic devices that learn continuously, in a patient-specific manner, and treat in closed-loop will result in improved therapeutic outcomes with higher sensitivities and specificities of treatment.

This CAREER project focuses on custom microelectronic systems design to enable intelligent, closed-loop neuromodulation in a device that aims to treat neurological conditions by dynamically delivering and adjusting therapeutic electrical stimulation in response to a patient’s real-time neural state. In a clinical context, the proposed research will advance medical device design and to validate the advancements with human cortical recordings.

Epilepsy, a chronic neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures, affects ~50 million people worldwide. Seizure frequency varies greatly from person to person and can severely impact a person’s quality of life.  As an aid to patients suffering from seizures, advisory systems have been developed that warn patients when a seizure is about to occur. The system first records EEG signals, either intracranially or on the scalp, and then performs classification to detect the onset or presence of a seizure. Closed loop implantable neuromodulators have also been deployed for seizure treatment. These systems detect seizure events within an acceptable latency (typically <5 s) and trigger neurostimulation to suppress the seizure. In some patients, EEG seizure patterns can change over time, which can be due to electrode displacement and impedance changes or shifts to the patients’ circadian profiles. Such changes would require regular retraining of the seizure detection algorithms to maintain high accuracy detection, and it is simply impractical to require such offline labeling and re-training on an ongoing basis.

Through the course of this grant, we developed integrated circuit-based systems that combined: (1) power efficient neural recording and stimulation (2) impedance measurement to cancel motion artifacts; (3) ultra-low energy and low area seizure detection classification that performs unsupervised online learning; (4) Ultra-low power, energy, and area seizure prediction classification with unsupervised online learning, capable of predicting seizures an average of 8.5 minutes in advance of a clinical seizure.

Our work demonstrates the first use of on-chip unsupervised online learning for seizure detection to dynamically adapt to changes in neural signal patterns over time and maintain high detection accuracy without external intervention. This will be referred to as Stochastic gradient-descent-based Online Unsupervised Logistic regression classifier (SOUL). SOUL is initially trained offline and then feature weights are updated in situ. Moreover, due to the computationally simple algorithm and architectural optimizations used, SOUL is significantly more energy efficient than the state-of-the-art on-chip seizure detectors. Utilizing our proposed technique can have a significant impact on the ease of use and longevity of closed-loop neuromodulation devices.

Early prediction of seizures can facilitate interventions before clinical symptoms manifest. Prior art has demonstrated the prediction of these events from electroencephalography (EEG) signals recorded from the scalp or intracranially. While some predictors offer on-chip retraining for accuracy tuning, to our knowledge, none of the prior art has used unsupervised online learning, which eliminates the need for external intervention to retrain the model. This work introduces SPIRIT (Stochastic-gradient-descent-based Predictor with Integrated Retraining and In situ accuracy Tuning), a SoC with the first on-chip seizure predictor that implements unsupervised online learning. SPIRIT’s classifier is 28x smaller and consumes 134x lower power than the state-of-the-art on-chip seizure predictor. SPIRIT's prediction classifier can predict seizures an average of 8.5 minutes in advance of clinical symptoms with high accuracy, which is life-changing for epilepsy patients. It would allow neuromodulation systems to start acting much earlier to shut down seizures, and it would allow patients to have advanced warning, which is life changing.

Our system also incorporates the first use of Zoom-based Analog Frontends (AFEs) that exhibit 23x higher input range and 12dB better Schrier Figure of Merit (FoM) than AFEs in prior seizure monitoring SoCs incorporating classifiers. This makes the complete system more robust to motion artifacts and other interferences, while still classifying seizures accurately and maximizing battery life through energy efficiency.

Through the course of this program PI Muller was an active foundational member of the SSCS Women in Circuits (WiC) group. The mission of the group is to improve representation by inspiring the next generation of women and to promote and improve the visibility of accomplished women in the field. Starting in 2018, Co-PI Muller has co-organized a WiC sponsored workshop at the international solid-state circuits conference (ISSCC), consisting of keynotes, technical talks, and round-table discussions on various technical and career topics with diverse speakers and discussion leaders. The workshops are free and attended by hundreds of students and young professionals. WiC also runs a Rising Stars workshop at ISSCC to bolster female and underrepresented students, Postdocs, and early career professionals. Furthermore, PI Muller co-organizes IEEE Brain workshops jointly with SSCS, aimed at student and young professional at the interface of neuroscience and microelectronics.
